item.title: The Female Factor: When Dad Becomes the Lead Parent
item.description: For one working mother, swapping traditional roles with her husband was liberating, and for her husband came empowerment.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.media:description: Katrin Bennhold's husband, Tomos, with their daughters Mali, 21 months, and Elena, four, in their London living room. Ms. Bennhold took the picture during a weekend visit in February.

item.title: India Ink: 4,000 Still Missing in Indian Floods
item.description: More than 4,000 people are still reported missing after flash floods hit Uttarakhand three weeks ago.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR
item.media:description: Vishal, a ten-year-old boy looking at photographs of his family members who have gone missing in the floods in Uttarakhand.

item.title: Chinese Police Open Fire on Unarmed Tibetans, Rights Groups Say
item.description: The groups said the weekend shootings injured nine people, two critically, at a 78th birthday celebration for the Dalai Lama.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Japan Warns of Threats From China and North Korea
item.description: An annual defense paper warns of the increasing possibility of a military confrontation with China and the danger of North Korea’s growing nuclear capability.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI

item.title: 18 Reported Injured in Beirut Explosion
item.description: The bombing came amid longstanding fears that Hezbollah would face attacks in response to its military intervention in Syria’s civil war.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Egypt’s Interim Government Seeks Quick Elections
item.description: A decree issued Monday by Adli Mansour pointed to a parliamentary ballot within about six months and a presidential vote to follow.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Supporters of deposed President Mohamed Morsi camped out in Rabaa Adawiya square on Tuesday.

item.title: Bolshoi Director Is Removed After Scandals
item.description: The replacement of Anatoly Iksanov by Vladimir Urin follows public tumult that included an acid attack on the company’s artistic director.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Crisis-Struck Europeans Losing Faith in Governments
item.description: Less than 10 percent of people in the countries hardest hit by the debt crisis believe their leaders are effectively fighting corruption, a study shows.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY

item.title: The Lede: Survivors of Asiana Flight 214 Describe Escape From Burning Plane
item.description: Video of two mothers describing their harrowing escape with their children from the plane that crash-landed at San Francisco International Airport on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER PRESTON
item.media:description: Lee Yoon-hye, Asiana Airlines Flight 214 flight attendant and cabin manager, spoke at a news conference in San Francisco on Sunday.

item.title: India Ink: The Food Security Debate in India
item.description: After accepting endemic undernutrition for too long as natural, India has made a breakthrough of sorts with the National Food Security Ordinance.
item.dc:creator: By JEAN DRÈZE
item.media:description: People checking the quality of rice grain at a ration shop in Mumbai, Maharashtra, on Friday.

item.title: The Lede: Der Spiegel Publishes Portion of Snowden Vetting Interview
item.description: When asked by the German magazine Der Spiegel what happens after a computer user becomes the focus of N.S.A. surveillance, Edward J. Snowden said, “They’re just owned.”
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL SCHWIRTZ

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: Attacks Kill at Least 21
item.description: Attacks around Iraq have killed at least 21 people, the latest in a spike of insurgent violence aimed at destabilizing the country, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Suicide Attack Kills 8
item.description: A suicide bomber on a motorcycle attacked a pro-government tribal elder’s vehicle in northwest Pakistan on Monday, killing at least eight people.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Rescue From Tigers
item.description: Rescuers on Monday reached five men trapped in trees by several Sumatran tigers for five days after the angry animals mauled a sixth man to death.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Dangerous Conditions Impede Inquiry Into Quebec Crash
item.description: The death toll in the vacation town where runaway railroad tank cars filled with oil derailed and exploded on Saturday grew to 13.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN
item.media:description: Railroad tank cars lay scattered at the site of the derailment in Lac-Mégantic on Monday.

item.title: Chilean Court Approves Extradition Request for Former Sect Leader
item.description: The Supreme Court took a step toward asking Germany to extradite a doctor who fled in 2011 after being convicted of the sexual abuse of minors in the 1990s.
item.category: European Center for Constitutional and Human Rights
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By PASCALE BONNEFOY

item.title: Spaniards Fight to Get Savings Back
item.description: Many Spaniards have seen their nest eggs virtually wiped out in what critics call a deceptive and possibly fraudulent sales campaign by banks.
item.dc:creator: By SUZANNE DALEY
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: A recent protest at a Bankia office in Madrid. Many bank customers found that the “preferred” instruments they were offered wiped out most of their savings.

item.title: Syrian Governing Party Ousts a Political Insider
item.description: Vice President Farouk al-Shara was removed from the government as Ghassan Hitto resigned his post in the opposition movement.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
National Coalition of Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Vice President Farouk al-Shara had come close to criticizing the Assad government.

item.title: Army Kills 51, Deepening Crisis in Egypt
item.description: In a sharp escalation of tensions Monday, Egyptian soldiers opened fire on hundreds of supporters of Mohamed Morsi, the ousted president, witnesses said. The military said armed assailants fired first.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:credit: Wissam Nassar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Wounded supporters of Mr. Morsi were treated in a makeshift hospital. At least 51 civilian demonstrators were killed and more than 400 were wounded, almost all of them by gunfire, health officials said.

item.title: World Briefing | the Americas: Canada: Storm Floods Toronto
item.description: An intense thunderstorm flooded expressways in and around Toronto, shut down the city’s transit system, closed one of its airports and led to power failures.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Istanbul Park Becomes Scene of Violence After Reopening
item.description: When a large group of people led by protest organizers marched toward Gezi Park, they were confronted by the police, who dispersed the crowd with water cannons and tear gas.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU
item.media:description: Three women tried to run from clouds of tear gas as the police clashed with demonstrators on Monday in Istanbul.

item.title: Police Eject Protesters From Istanbul Park
item.description: Authorities reopened Gezi Park in Taksim Square on Monday, but police arrested scores of protesters who gathered there.

item.title: Bloody Day in Unrest Widens the Rupture Among Ordinary Egyptians
item.description: The divisions have marked Cairo’s geography, with the pro-military and pro-Morsi camps occupying different squares, blocking traffic, erecting tents and rigging up loudspeakers.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD and KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: A supporter of President Mohamed Morsi holding up the Koran at a mosque in the Nasr City district in Cairo on Monday.

item.title: Judge Urges President to Address Prison Strike
item.description: In a four-page ruling, Judge Gladys Kessler rejected a request by a detainee to bar the military from force-feeding him, but the judge made an appeal to President Obama to address the issue.
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: In Asiana Crash Investigation, Early Focus Is on the Crew’s Actions
item.description: Early examinations showed no obvious mechanical problems with the Boeing 777, which crashed in San Francisco, killing two passengers.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW L. WALD and NORIMITSU ONISHI
item.media:description: An Asiana jet taxied on Monday past the wreck of the airline’s Flight 214, which crashed on Saturday on approach to San Francisco International Airport.
